meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Democrats in Congress Push for Climate Bills Democrats in Congress are increasingly determined to impose mandatory controls on carbon dioxide emissions by smokestack industries, wresting control of the issue from the White House. Four major Democratic measures have been announced, and lobbyists expected one or a blend of them to pass this year or next.
PAGE A24

Cancer Deaths Down For Second Straight Year The number of cancer deaths in the United States has dropped for the second year in a row, the American Cancer Society reported. The finding suggests that the small drop reported last year -- the first in more than 70 years -- was not merely a statistical fluke, the researchers said.
PAGE A14

Turning a Museum's Walls Into Wide Screens Doug Aitken's monumental video projection piece, ''Sleepwalkers,'' turns the Museum of Modern Art's sleek exterior into a postmodern screen for the house that Cubism built. A review by Roberta Smith.
THE ARTS, PAGE E5

Senator Clinton Backs Limits Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, back from Iraq, said she wanted limits on the White House's handling of the war. Three other senators proposed a resolution against a troop increase in Iraq.
PAGE A10
Offer for Tribune Company Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle offered $500 million for the largest stake in the Tribune Company, which owns The Los Angeles Times and other newspapers.
PAGE C1
A Place on the Shelf Americans are personalizing their space even after death with cremation urns designed by artists and craftspeople, like the textured steel urn, left, by Tony Knapp of Seattle.
PAGE F1

Democrats in Congress Push for Climate Bills Democrats in Congress are increasingly determined to impose mandatory controls on carbon dioxide emissions by smokestack industries, wresting control of the issue from the White House. Four major Democratic measures have been announced, and lobbyists expected one or a blend of them to pass this year or next.
PAGE A24

Cancer Deaths Down For Second Straight Year The number of cancer deaths in the United States has dropped for the second year in a row, the American Cancer Society reported. The finding suggests that the small drop reported last year -- the first in more than 70 years -- was not merely a statistical fluke, the researchers said.
PAGE A14

Turning a Museum's Walls Into Wide Screens Doug Aitken's monumental video projection piece, ''Sleepwalkers,'' turns the Museum of Modern Art's sleek exterior into a postmodern screen for the house that Cubism built. A review by Roberta Smith.
THE ARTS, PAGE E5

Senator Clinton Backs Limits Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, back from Iraq, said she wanted limits on the White House's handling of the war. Three other senators proposed a resolution against a troop increase in Iraq.
PAGE A10
Offer for Tribune Company Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle offered $500 million for the largest stake in the Tribune Company, which owns The Los Angeles Times and other newspapers.
PAGE C1
A Place on the Shelf Americans are personalizing their space even after death with cremation urns designed by artists and craftspeople, like the textured steel urn, left, by Tony Knapp of Seattle.
